bibl.title: Letter from Burton J. Hendrick to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 14, 1924

div1.p: Burton informs Kean that the piece published in World's Work, by Marie Gorgas, was an excerpt of her larger work in which Reed does receive credit.

div1.head: Letter from Burton J. Hendrick to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 14, 1924
div1.opener:
From Burton Hendrick
THE WORLD'S WORK
GARDEN CITY NEW YORK
April 14, 1924.
My dear Colonel Kean:
div1.p:
I have your letter of April 10th with its
valuable enclosure. The main trouble is that
the chapter published in the magazine is only
about one-third of the chapter as written and
as it will be published in the book. In the
complete version most of the points that you
make are taken up in detail and I think the
relation of Dr. Walter Reed to the yellow
fever discovery is accurately and fairly des-
cribed. In fact we have been at particular
pains to make clear the complete indebtedness
of Gorgas to Reed's work. The letters that
passed between the two men are quoted in detail
and will be published in full as an appendix
to the book. The manuscript is being very
carefully read by Dr. Carter who, I think, is
generally regarded as the greatest living expert
on yellow fever and its history.

I wish you would let me keep your memorandum
to use in preparing this chapter for book publica-
Col. J. R. Kean,
Headquarters First Corps Area,
Army Base,
Boston, 9, Mass.
THE WORLD'S WORK
GARDEN CITY NEW YORK
-2-
tion. I should like very much to take up
the points you raise still further with
Dr. Carter and Mrs. Gorgas.
With many thanks for your kindness,
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, Burton J. Hendrick. Sent to MCaw April 16
